text:
The no politics rule came out about 4 years ago, after someone in the US got unhappy when they found that the majority of the julia community had very different political views to them.
and that person no longer is on slack AFAIK.

Though I am sure there are more than one person, I think the principle objector is gone.

text: I think it's a good rule for two reasons. First, because politics has already seeped into so many people's lives. It's good to have communities where you get a break from it. And second because it's all fun and games until someone flips because they can't handle the fact that someone is an anarchist / communist / fascist / whatever.

text:
OTOH, I have seen a compelling arguement (that i am not going to try to recreate) that basically made the point that a no-politics rule is in practice a pro-status quo rule.
And that it is trivially (and indeed unintentionally)  harmful to minorities.
Since complaining about discimination against minority not in the context o the topic of the forum (in this off-topic channel), is considered a political statement.
But it may indeed be part of the <#C680MM7D4|random> things that are just like part of their lives.

Kind of like me complaining about use of  Fahrenheit is just like part of my life.
